name.text: 14.4.2 The area of a surface of revolution

questiontext.text:
The area of a surface of revolution

In previous workbooks we found an expression for the volume of a solid of revolution. Here we consider the more complicated problem of formulating an expression for the surface area of a solid of revolution.


The Figure above shows the portion of the curve \(y(x)\) between \(x = a\) and \(x = b\) which is rotated around the \(x\) axis through \(360^{\circ}\). A small disc, of thickness \(\delta x\), of the solid of revolution has been selected. Its radius is \(y\) and so its circumference has length \(2 \pi y\). (As usual we assume \(\delta x\) is ‘small’ so that the curved part of \(y(x)\) representing the hypotenuse of the highlighted ‘triangle’ can be regarded as straight). This surface ‘ribbon’, shown shaded, has a length \(2 \pi y\) and a width \(\sqrt{(\delta x)^2 + (\delta y)^2}\) and so its area is, to a good approximation, \(2 \pi y \sqrt{(\delta x)^2 + (\delta y)^2}\). We now let \(\delta x \to 0\) to obtain the result in the Key Point below:

Key Point

Given a curve with equation \(y = f(x)\), then the surface area of the solid generated by rotating that part of the curve between the points where \(x = a\) and \(x = b\) around the \(x\) axis is given by the formula: \[\text{area of surface} = \int_a^b 2 \pi y \sqrt{1+\left(\frac{\mathrm{d}y}{\mathrm{d}x}\right)^2} \ \mathrm{d}x\]
